prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Setup #1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: A [OIII]88 line survey for MACS1149-JD: Setupt #1

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request to use "Spectral Line" mode with 4 tunings set by manually instead of "Spectral Scan" mode with 5 tunings set by automatically which requires much more calibration time. We prefer FDM with a spectral average to TDM in order to sample the target emission line with a FWHM of 60 km/s by a finer resolution. Applying the spectral average factor of 16, we use the BaseBand set up of 1.875 GHz with 7.813 MHz resolution. The achieved velocity resolution is 7.60 km/s which allows us to sample the expected FWHM of 60 km/s by about 8 elements. We will further reduce the resolution up to 30 km/s in order to reach a high enough signal-to-noise ratio.

The size along the major axis of the target galaxy is about 0.6 arcsec and the possible extension is at most 1.0 arcsec found in HST/WFC3 images. Thus, we request C36-1, 2, or -3 configurations which give the angular resolution of 1.0, 0.5, or 0.4 arcsec, respectively.

The expected peak flux density of the [OIII] line is typically 2.4 mJy for the case of the gravitational magnification of 14.5 (see SJ). In the other case, the expected peak flux density is a factor of 1.5 higher. To reach about 5-sigma detection of the 2.4 mJy line, we request a 0.5 mJy (1-sigma) sensitivity with a bandwidth of 30 km/s which is a half of the expected line FWHM of 60 km/s. For the dust continuum, we expect about 5-sigma detection with the same exposure time.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Setup #2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: A [OIII]88 line survey for MACS1149-JD: Setupt #2

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request to use "Spectral Line" mode with 4 tunings set by manually instead of "Spectral Scan" mode with 5 tunings set by automatically which requires much more calibration time. Applying the spectral average factor of 16, we use the BaseBand set up of 1.875 GHz with 7.813 MHz resolution. We will further reduce the resolution up to 30 km/s in order to reach a high enough signal-to-noise ratio.

The size along the major axis of the target galaxy is about 0.6 arcsec and the possible extension is at most 1.0 arcsec found in HST/WFC3 images. Thus, we request C36-1, 2, or -3 configurations which give the angular resolution of 1.0, 0.5, or 0.4 arcsec, respectively.

The expected peak flux density of the [OIII] line is typically 2.4 mJy for the case of the gravitational magnification of 14.5 (see SJ). In the other case, the expected peak flux density is a factor of 1.5 higher. To reach about 5-sigma detection of the 2.4 mJy line, we request a 0.5 mJy (1-sigma) sensitivity with a bandwidth of 30 km/s which is a half of the expected line FWHM of 60 km/s. For the dust continuum, we expect about 5-sigma detection with the same exposure time.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Setup #3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: A [OIII]88 line survey for MACS1149-JD: Setupt #3

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request to use "Spectral Line" mode with 4 tunings set by manually instead of "Spectral Scan" mode with 5 tunings set by automatically which requires much more calibration time. We prefer FDM with a spectral average to TDM in order to sample the target emission line with a FWHM of 60 km/s by a finer resolution. Applying the spectral average factor of 16, we use the BaseBand set up of 1.875 GHz with 7.813 MHz resolution. The achieved velocity resolution is 7.43 km/s which allows us to sample the expected FWHM of 60 km/s by about 8 elements. We will further reduce the resolution up to 30 km/s in order to reach a high enough signal-to-noise ratio.

The size along the major axis of the target galaxy is about 0.6 arcsec and the possible extension is at most 1.0 arcsec found in HST/WFC3 images. Thus, we request C36-1, 2, or -3 configurations which give the angular resolution of 1.0, 0.5, or 0.4 arcsec, respectively.

The expected peak flux density of the [OIII] line is typically 2.4 mJy for the case of the gravitational magnification of 14.5 (see SJ). In the other case, the expected peak flux density is a factor of 1.5 higher. To reach about 5-sigma detection of the 2.4 mJy line, we request a 0.5 mJy (1-sigma) sensitivity with a bandwidth of 30 km/s which is a half of the expected line FWHM of 60 km/s. For the dust continuum, we expect about 5-sigma detection with the same exposure time.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Setup #4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: A [OIII]88 line survey for MACS1149-JD: Setupt #4

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request to use "Spectral Line" mode with 4 tunings set by manually instead of "Spectral Scan" mode with 5 tunings set by automatically which requires much more calibration time. We prefer FDM with a spectral average to TDM in order to sample the target emission line with a FWHM of 60 km/s by a finer resolution. Applying the spectral average factor of 16, we use the BaseBand set up of 1.875 GHz with 7.813 MHz resolution. The achieved velocity resolution is 7.35 km/s which allows us to sample the expected FWHM of 60 km/s by about 8 elements. We will further reduce the resolution up to 30 km/s in order to reach a high enough signal-to-noise ratio.

The size along the major axis of the target galaxy is about 0.6 arcsec and the possible extension is at most 1.0 arcsec found in HST/WFC3 images. Thus, we request C36-1, 2, or -3 configurations which give the angular resolution of 1.0, 0.5, or 0.4 arcsec, respectively.

The expected peak flux density of the [OIII] line is typically 2.4 mJy for the case of the gravitational magnification of 14.5 (see SJ). In the other case, the expected peak flux density is a factor of 1.5 higher. To reach about 5-sigma detection of the 2.4 mJy line, we request a 0.5 mJy (1-sigma) sensitivity with a bandwidth of 30 km/s which is a half of the expected line FWHM of 60 km/s. For the dust continuum, we expect about 5-sigma detection with the same exposure time.
The frequency range in this set up overlaps with that in the set up #1 which gives about a 0.75 mJy (1-sigma) sensitivity at the frequency. Therefore, a 0.6 mJy (1-sigma) sensitivity is sufficient to reach a 0.5 mJy (1-sigma) sensitivity after combining both data.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose ALMA observations for a brightest (<26 AB) and most reliable galaxy candidate at z~10 in order to detect the far-infrared [OIII] 88.33 micron emission line redshifted into Band 7. These observations will spectroscopically confirm the redshift of the candidate, break the current spectroscopic redshift record, and put the first constraint on baryon physics of galaxy formation in the pre-reionization era. We will also detect the dust continuum from the galaxy with a high significance even in the case of non-detection of the line and constrain formation and evolution processes of these tiny solid particles in the earliest Universe.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
